page.title: 14Colwich Junction
page.content: Colwich Station was at the junction of the North Staffordshire Railway with the London North Western Railway. The Station House has recently been sand blasted, removing the grime of years and the soot of the Age of Steam, revealing a fine example of Staffordshire Railway architecture. A footbridge still crosses the lines but the level crossing, sidings, turntable, water tower and signal box have long gone, soon after the closure of the station in 1954. The road was cut under the railway lines as the amount of road traffic increased making it impracticable to use a level crossing on the main line to London. Railway workers were housed in two terraces, one on each side of the brigde over the road. These are now privately owned, some by former railwaymen.
